For a side branding themselves as idealists and over-achievers, as a fan-owned footballing dreamland attempting to establish themselves as a Premier League side deserving of the name, this was both horrifically archaic and shockingly small-time.

What should have been another in the club’s ever-growing litany of great nights now ought to be remembered for this betrayal by the home support. Luton should apologise on behalf of their fans as soon as possible.

This could have been worse. Manchester City had 21 shots on goal, three more than Liverpool managed in their 9-0 demolition of Bournemouth last season, and yet only managed to score six. Always look for the positives, as they say. There were not many more.
If you are going to lose at places like the Etihad – and frankly no other result looked possible – the best you could hope for would be to return to the south coast with your squad intact.
The loss of the wonderfully talented Alex Scott, making only his third start since his £25 million move from Bristol City meant Andoni Iraola was denied even this modest satisfaction.
There is another positive to cling to. After their 9-0 evisceration at Anfield last season, Bournemouth did not lose any of their next six matches. They did, however, sack their manager.

No club in the history of top-flight English football has lost its first six home games, as Burnley have done this season. Given that the first five were against Manchester City, Aston Villa, Tottenham, Manchester United and Chelsea, this might have been dismissed as a statistical quirk. Crystal Palace, however, are not and never have been one of the Premier League’s big boys.

This was probably a more significant defeat than any of the others Vincent Kompany’s side has suffered at Turf Moor. Again, the Burnley manager talked of ‘fine margins’ and ‘individual errors’ but it may be time to wonder if he has the players to persist with the kind of open, attractive football that saw them promoted as champions.

The Palace manager, Roy Hodgson, may have praised Burnley’s style of football but you can always be generous in victory. The next visitors to Turf Moor are West Ham, Sheffield United and Everton. If after then, Burnley have lost their seventh, eighth and ninth matches at home, Kompany may no longer be manager, which would be something of a pity.

This is no time for analysis at Bramall Lane. The fact is that Sheffield United have won a match, the last of the 92 clubs to do so. That alone should remove a huge burden from Paul Heckingbottom and his players.

Robbie Savage, who was part of a Derby side that went through the 2007-08 season winning just once and picking up 11 points, remarked how a succession of lost matches poisoned everything around the dressing room until some players wondered if it were worth carrying on. There is still a danger of that happening at Sheffield United.
But, however soft the penalty was which decided the contest with Wolves, Heckingbottom can use the result as a rallying point, especially in their next home fixture against Bournemouth.

title: Rugby news: No Saracens boos for Owen Farrell, Eddie Jones ducks questions and poor crowds blight WXV1
lead: The big talking points from rugby across Europe this weekend
author: Hugh Godwin

body.text: Our weekend preview bigged up the return to fitness this season of ­Tyrone Green for Harlequins, and the 25-year-old South African did not disappoint in his club’s 40-12 home victory over winless Newcastle in the Premiership.

England’s Marcus Smith, a second-half substitute for Jarrod Evans, launched a cross-kick to the right wing in the 75th minute which, good though it was, needed Green to dive full-length to catch the ball while making sure to land millimetres inside the touchline in the in-goal – an early contender for try of the season.

“Tyrone has been out for a long time and that connection between him and Marcus is pretty special,” said Billy Millard, Harlequins’ director of rugby. “Obviously they haven’t played [together] for a while but Tyrone is getting better and better each week. From minute one, Marcus is bouncing and talking and all over them, so it’s awesome to have him back.”
WHAT HAVE WE JUST SEEN?! 😱Stop what you're doing and watch this RIDICULOUS try from Tyrone Green 🤯#GallagherPrem | #HARvNEW | @Harlequins pic.twitter.com/iy5rBBu9aw
With just 10 clubs in the Premiership now, the league season comprises only 20 fixtures for whoever wins the title next June, but rotation is still a feature.
Saracens had all their big-name England players straight back from the World Cup, while opponents Leicester chose to rest theirs.

So, a mere eight days on from contesting the bronze-medal match in Paris, Ben Earl and his foot speed were among the highlights for Sarries, while Owen Farrell did not have to hear his name booed like it was in France – not even when he took the conservative option of penalty kicks at goal when his side was 26-10 and 29-17 up.

Afterwards Farrell was chased for his autograph by a group of adoring young fans, but it made the mind flick back 20 years to Jonny Wilkinson spending up to an hour after a match doing the same thing. That is what winning a World Cup can do for capturing the imagination.

Saracens, by the way, began a new publicity campaign by donating £8,000 for their four tries to the Sickle Cell Society, who research the distressing blood disorder that disproportionately affects those of African and Caribbean heritage. One full row of seats in the East Stand at StoneX stadium has been redesignated “Row Ro”, to highlight the variation of the RH positive blood type that is chronically short of donors in the UK.

🪑 To highlight those with the Ro Blood Type, we will rebrand Row R at StoneX Stadium as Row Ro, to symbolise the rarest blood type for sickle cell disorder. Full Story 👇 #YourSaracens💫#BloodFromAStoneX@StoneX_Official

In Saturday’s other Premiership match, Northampton’s young England flanker Tom Pearson was on the scoresheet, taking another of the cool midfield lines that mark out his running talent, as Saints beat Bath 24-18.

Alun Wyn Jones had it put to him on the pitch that “all good things come to an end” after he played for the Barbarians against his beloved Wales, at which moment the 170-Test legend had to pause for the cheers of a 53,271 crowd. Then, typically of the former Wales captain, Jones made mention of fellow Test retirees Leigh Halfpenny, Justin Tipuric and “Dan Biggar, who wasn’t here today”.

Indeed Biggar was in France, playing for Toulon, where anyone who has ever had a back spasm or sciatica would recognise the pain felt by the fly-half as he crumpled to the ground while running up to take a conversion. Biggar was substituted and his club lost 26-22 at Perpignan.

#TOP14 – Le coup dur de la J5Impressionnante image de l'ouvreur du @RCTofficiel foudroyé par une douleur au dos avant de buter 😰Souhaitons un prompt rétablissement à Dan Biggar 🙏 pic.twitter.com/YCDbOo5KlC
Back in Cardiff, Jones gave thanks to his wife and children, commenting with a degree of hope: “They’re not going to stop growing, and neither is Welsh rugby.”

Also typically of the guarded Jones, who arguably epitomises rugby’s existential struggle between the team ethos and the need for individuals to do more to promote themselves and the sport, he had nothing to say on his future plans beyond maybe a couple more games for Toulon and “a few glasses of red and a lie in the sun” – which was a shame when he had 50,000-plus supportive ticket-buyers hanging on his words.

Sadly, bad publicity dogged what should have been a celebratory fixture. In addition to it being scheduled to clash with the Scarlets-Cardiff (31-25) derby and other URC matches, the Barbarians’ big-name coaches, Eddie Jones and Scott Robertson – the incoming All Blacks head coach – did not attend the customary post-match press conference on a day when their Fiji lock, Api Ratuniyarawa, had appeared in Cardiff Magistrates’ Court over alleged incidents of sexual assault involving three women in a nightclub earlier in the week.

Still on crowds and how to attract and react to them, England captain Marlie Packer was grumbling about the poor attendances for the inaugural WXV1 in New Zealand as her Red Roses won Saturday’s final, 33-12 over the Black Ferns in front of 6,000 spectators at Auckland’s Mount Smart Stadium.

It may have been partly due to the unfamiliar new competition, and it will certainly be different at the next Rugby World Cup, in England in 2025. For now, one thought is that if WXV is the name of the women’s global competition between World Cups, wouldn’t it be joined-up thinking for the men’s as yet untitled equivalent – variously trailed as the Nations Cup, Nations Championship or World League – to be called the MXV? It might do, if the top division of the new event from 2026 was owned by World Rugby but, as we know, it isn’t – the Six Nations and Sanzaar are in charge instead.
Packer, whose predecessor as captain, Sarah Hunter, is now on England’s coaching staff, was subsequently named World Rugby Women’s Player of the Year.

title: Cricket World Cup: Moeen Ali tells England to ditch old players and ‘start again’ with exciting youngsters
lead: The writing was on the wall and we just didn’t see it, admits Moeen after ageing England are knocked out of the World Cup by Australia
author: Chris Stocks

body.text: PUNE — Moeen Ali pulled no punches in the wake of England’s latest World Cup horror show against Australia, admitting the one-day team needs a complete rebuild after this nightmare campaign is over.
Moeen, 36, is one of 11 players in the squad over the age of 30 and all of them have been selected in the past three games.

Loyalty to the core of the 2019 World Cup-winning squad has not worked, with Jos Buttler’s men rock bottom of the standings after six defeats in seven matches so far, with the latest by Australia on Saturday officially knocking the defending champions out of the tournament with two games yet to play.

Asked if the simple explanation for an abysmal World Cup and the end of a successful white-ball era that has included two major tournament wins, including last year’s T20 World Cup in Australia, was just the fact the players are getting old, Moeen said: “Yeah. I think it’s more everything good comes to an end and maybe the writing was on the wall and we just didn’t see it as players.

“I just think everything good comes to an end at some point. It’s very exciting because going forward we’ve got some really good players we know will come back into the squad, with that fearless playing, so that start we had in 2015 could start again.

“I think if I was in charge I’d play the younger guys. I’d just start again and I’m sure they’re going to do that. It’s common sense more than anything. You want that fearless approach again and it’s a great time to start again.”
Moeen, who travelled with the squad to Pune on Sunday ahead of England’s penultimate World Cup match against the Netherlands on Wednesday, admits he will probably not be part of that 50-over rebuild.

“I’m obviously going to speak to Jos and Motty [coach Matthew Mott] and see whether they want me around or whatever, I don’t know,” he said. “If they say, ‘look we’re going to go with younger players and start again’ then I’m more than happy. I get it, I understand and like I said, everything good comes to an end at some point.”

England have the likes of Phil Salt, Will Jacks, Zak Crawley, Ben Duckett, Sam Hain and Rehan Ahmed waiting in the wings ready to come into the 50-over team for next month’s three-match series in the West Indies. They are also likely to form part of the rebuild as England look towards the 2027 World Cup in South Africa, Zimbabwe and Namibia.

After England’s first-round exit at the 2015 World Cup in Australia and New Zealand, five players who had not been part of that dire campaign – Jason Roy, Ben Stokes, Sam Billings, Adil Rashid and Liam Plunkett – came straight into the XI for the team’s next ODI against New Zealand at Edgbaston the following summer.
Moeen expects a similar turnover after this tournament ends with England’s final group match against Pakistan in Kolkata on Saturday.
“I look at it as an exciting time going forward because there are so many good players, we know they are coming,” he said.

“Anything could happen, there are still another four years before the next World Cup. Like 2015, we were terrible in the World Cup and we started again, almost started fresh and it can be exciting going forward.”

title: Mauricio Pochettino admits he could return to Tottenham one day: ‘The feeling at Chelsea is not the same’
lead: The Argentine hopes to stay at Chelsea for another 25 years but says ‘you never know in football’ as he faces his former club
author: Neil Mahoney

body.text: Mauricio Pochettino says he “cannot lie” about his relationship with Chelsea not yet being as strong as the one he forged at Tottenham during his time there.
And while his intention is to be at Stamford Bridge for many years to come, he admits he would be open to managing Spurs again at some point should circumstances change.
The Argentine returns to his former club for the first time as an opposing manager on Monday night.
The London derby offers Pochettino and his staff a chance to meet people he spent five years working with during his ascent to stardom in English football.
Asked whether he could ever see himself back in north London, Pochettino said: “Who knows? It’s like life, you never know what is going to happen tomorrow.
“We need to enjoy today and not look too much in the future, in the long term. But, why not?”
Pochettino could still be booed by supporters despite reaching the Champions League final and helping to build the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium.

It is likely seeing Pochettino in Chelsea colours will test the relationship he built up with Spurs fans due to the fierce rivalry between the two clubs, but he doesn’t see it as a barrier to an eventual return.
“Why? Hopefully, I can stay here until I die – 20 or 25 years, but you never know in football. For sure, if I’m not working, maybe if they want me one day… Why not?”

Pochettino was much admired at Spurs but he has struggled to build such a bond in his early days at Chelsea. He was then asked whether he feels he could “love” Chelsea like he did Tottenham, responding: “After four months? I cannot lie [it is not the same feeling],” he said.

“I hope we can arrive on the same level that I had at Tottenham because then it would mean we are doing well here. Of course, I expect one day to be on the same level but I cannot lie, at the moment, no. It is a tough situation.”
Chelsea have dropped into the bottom half of the table but Ange Postegcolou’s side would go back to the top of the table with a win.
Against that backdrop, Pochettino’s kind words risk angering some Chelsea fans but he explained he simply wanted to be honest. “We need to be natural and not be fake,” he said.
“I don’t want to be a hypocrite and say something I do not feel or that we are still in the process of creating. I am just going to be natural and enjoy a great game, which I want to win.”

title: Tottenham fans warn Mauricio Pochettino will face a ‘crescendo of boos’ on his return with Chelsea
lead: Martin Buhagiar of the Tottenham supporters’ trust on the reception the former fan favourite can expect after joining their London rivals
author: Oliver Young-Myles

body.text: Tottenham‘s limp Champions League exit to AC Milan in March was the point at which supporters finally had enough of years of negative tactics, uninspiring football, and haughty managers. “He’s magic you know, Mauricio Pochettino,” was the defiant message chanted loud and proud by the masses as they trudged towards the turnstiles.

When Antonio Conte was dismissed soon after it looked as though the stars were aligning for Pochettino to make a romantic return to north London. The Argentine was out of work after a bruising if relatively successful spell at PSG, while Daniel Levy was on the lookout for another new manager at arguably his lowest point in over two decades as chairman. Pochettino was the obvious choice, but not the chosen one.

When a black-suited Pochettino strides out of the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium tunnel towards the touchline on Monday night for the first time in almost four years, it will be as Chelsea’s manager. Many of the home fans who clamoured for his return will give him a welcome back. Of sorts.
In the build-up to the game, Spurs fans have been asking themselves the same philosophical question: to boo or not to boo?
“I think he’ll probably walk out to a crescendo of boos,” Martin Buhagiar, co-chair of the Tottenham Hotspur Supporter’s Trust tells .
“That isn’t necessarily my opinion of how he should be greeted back but I think it’s what is likely to happen given that he’s now joined Chelsea. It seems inevitable really.”
Pochettino made Spurs fans dream, transforming an underperforming rabble into title challengers and Champions League finalists.
He understood the club in a way that countless others both before and since did not, building a young, entertaining team that captured the hearts and minds of the fanbase.

Such was the depth of feeling towards him, the majority of fans did not want him to go even though the time was probably right. Levy acknowledged that sacking him was the hardest decision he had to make in almost 20 years of chairmanship.

And so the cult of Pochettino loomed unhelpfully over the club for the best part of four years. Quite literally, when a flag featuring Pochettino in front of an Argentina flag provided the visual backdrop to Jose Mourinho’s first home game.
Which is why his move to Chelsea has been interpreted in some quarters as an act of betrayal. Some will boo him, others will offer polite applause, but most, perhaps, will sit and do nothing.
“I’ll always be very grateful to Mauricio Pochettino for all that he did at the club,” says Buhagiar, who falls into the latter category.

“What he did at the club will stand the test of time. The football was great and we had a connection with the team for the first time in years. The connection that we have with Postecoglou and his team we’ve not had that since Pochettino left and the last time that I had that connection with a team before that was probably Terry Venables [in the 1990s].

“Football fans should be free to applaud and boo whoever they like but for me personally, my love for the club is greater than my dislike for Chelsea so I’d rather remember what he did for my football club than care what he’s doing now.”

Speaking on Friday, Pochettino said he would not spend time “guessing” how he may be received by the Spurs faithful before insisting that any negative expression would not “change my emotions, my view, my feelings about a club where we spent an unbelievable journey.”

He also issued a defence of his decision to join one of the club’s fiercest rivals, reiterating that he would never manage Barcelona, Arsenal, or Rosario Central out of respect to Espanyol, Spurs and Newell’s Old Boys.
“I don’t think he helps himself by saying he wouldn’t manage Arsenal because for a lot of Spurs fans the dislike for Chelsea is as high as it is for Arsenal,” Buhagiar contests.
“Mauricio knows the club, he was at Spurs long enough. We’re Chelsea’s biggest rivals. If you ask Chelsea fans who they dislike the most it will always be Tottenham. He knows that.”

Of more pressing importance for Pochettino is the game itself. Chelsea have won only three of their opening 10 Premier League games this season, slumping to a disappointing 2-0 home defeat to Brentford last time out. A loss at Spurs would extend the gap between the two clubs in the table to 17 points.

Spurs’ unexpectedly fast start is why fans who pined for Pochettino are now loving Big Ange instead. Spurs have taken 26 points from a possible 33, a record-breaking return for a new Premier League manager at this stage of a campaign.
Postecoglou’s impact has been so swift and vast that fans have finally moved on from Pochettino.

“I think the fact that Ange is doing such an incredible job means we’re enjoying the ride and not necessarily worrying about any of our rivals,” Buhagiar says. “So in a funny kind of way that probably helps Pochettino out a bit.”

title: Money Clinic: ‘How can I save enough to retire comfortably by 55 – and what are the downsides?
lead: A reader would like to retire early – but is unsure whether the sacrifices required are worth it
author: Tom Selby

body.text: I’ve been reading about the FIRE (Financial Independence, Retire Early) movement recently and the idea of retiring early is pretty appealing. What are the pros and cons? How easy is it to enjoy a decent standard of living if you retire at, say, 55?

Stopping work as soon as possible remains a dream for many people. But if you aren’t super-wealthy, early retirement will usually require some serious saving while you’re young and an ultra-frugal lifestyle – or a combination of the two.

In fact, analysis carried out by the Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) suggests while a larger chunk of the wealthiest in society are able to retire earlier compared with the start of the millennium, those with less wealth are generally more likely to work well into their 60s and beyond. Lower levels of financial security (for example, many people still have mortgages to pay off) and rises in the state pension age are among the possible reasons.
That is not to say retiring in your 50s is impossible – you just need to be realistic about what is achievable and the long-term implications.

For starters, you usually cannot access your private pension before age 55, with this minimum access age set to rise to 57 in 2028. It is possible to retire before this age, but you’d need non-pension assets, such as Isas or buy-to-let property, to support your lifestyle until you can access your retirement pot.

You also need to factor in the availability (or lack thereof) of the state pension. This is a valuable source of retirement income for millions of Brits but at the moment it only becomes available from your 66 birthday. The state pension age is then scheduled to rise to 67 by 2028 and 68 by 2046. The full state pension is worth just over £10,600 a year in 2023.

In terms of the pros and cons of early retirement, the obvious pro is that you will have more time to relax and do the things you enjoy doing. For lots of people, that single outcome is worth huge amounts of sacrifice. If you have paid off your mortgage and expect lower living costs when you stop working, early retirement will be more achievable.

But if you want to retire early and plan to travel, eat out at nice restaurants or generally have an active and potentially expensive lifestyle, you will need to build up a substantial pot of money to pay for it. Using tax-incentivised vehicles like pensions and ISAs will help with this. This will likely require you to sacrifice more on your lifestyle when you are younger. If you don’t do this, you’ll either need to cut your cloth significantly to make your retirement income plan sustainable, or risk running out of money too soon.

If you are eyeing early retirement, make sure you’ve sat down, ideally with a regulated adviser, and thought carefully about your spending plans and the impact retiring earlier will have on these plans.

It’s worth remembering you might also miss out on tax-free investment growth if you start drawing an income from your pension early. In fact, by leaving your fund invested for longer, you have the potential to get the double boost of increasing the value of your pension through long-term growth as well as not depleting it through withdrawals.

Take, for example, someone with a £300,000 pension pot at age 55. They have already taken their 25 per cent tax-free cash and choose to start taking an income from their pot. If they keep their pension invested in ‘drawdown’ and enjoy 4 per cent investment growth after charges each year, that pot could deliver an annual income of around £10,500 a year until their mid-90s (assuming the income rises each year by 2 per cent, in line with the Bank of England’s inflation target).

If, however, they wait until age 65 to access their pension and their fund grows by 4 per cent per year over that intervening period, they could have a fund worth just shy of £450,000 to draw an income from. Assuming they still want their pot to last until their mid-90s, an annual income of around £18,500 a year (again rising each year by 2 per cent) could now be sustainable (again, assuming investment returns are 4 per cent per year after charges).

In addition, there are tax consequences that need to be considered when accessing your pension. Once you take taxable income flexibly from your retirement pot, your annual allowance – the maximum you can pay into a pension each year before being hit with a tax charge – will drop from £60,000 to £10,000, reducing your ability to make top-up contributions if your plans or circumstances change. Pensions are also extremely tax efficient on death, so if passing money onto loved ones is a priority it can often make sense to access your pension last of all your assets.

You should take a moment to consider the reality of early retirement too – because it isn’t just about the money. What do you plan to do with your time? Will you have enough going on to stimulate you? The ‘FIRE’ movement you mention in your question tends to advocate fairly extreme saving strategies, which won’t be realistic or desirable for lots of people.

For many, taking on part-time work when transitioning towards retirement will be attractive as it allows you to remain active, earn an extra income but work fewer hours than previously. However, this won’t be possible for everyone, particularly those who have physical jobs they might struggle to continue doing in their later years.

title: ‘My partner earns more than me. Should we split our 2k mortgage equally or should he pay more?’
lead: A reader and her partner have a dilemma over how they should split their mortgage costs
author: Callum Mason

body.text: Me and my partner have just got a mortgage on our first house together. The cost is £2,000 per month, which is a little more than we expected, but it’s comfortable with our salaries.

We aren’t married – though we plan to get engaged later this year – and don’t yet have a joint bank account. Before this, we’ve generally kept our finances quite separate, but obviously that becomes quite difficult once you have a mortgage together.

He earns 60k and I earn 50k, and my view is that I should pay a little less towards the mortgage to reflect that, but he thinks we should split the costs 50-50, as we do with everything else. Who is in the right?

This is a very difficult dilemma and I can very much understand both perspectives. Ultimately, you can only come to a conclusion together, as only as a couple do you understand your full circumstances.

I would be inclined to agree with you, that you should split the costs according to salary. I understand that you don’t have linked finances, but by entering into a mortgage together, your money does inevitably become intertwined, as you own an asset, and share debt together.

Of course, you may also bring other things to this asset other than purely financial elements. Perhaps you’re better at home improvements, DIY, or upkeep? Do you do more in terms of admin for your household? These things aren’t quantifiable but it’s unlikely they’re split exactly equally.
It would make sense – especially as the gap isn’t great between what you earn – to share that according to what you can afford.
In this scenario, I don’t think there is a hard and fast right and wrong answer as it will totally depend on you as a couple.
I can understand wanting to split by salary, as you may feel out of pocket, but often splitting a bill this important 50-50 can be beneficial for your relationship.

This is because you will both be equal in your “ownership” of the home i.e. if there are any disagreements about decorating or renovation, for example, there is no chance of one person saying “I pay more therefore I have the final say”.
Equally if the worst comes to the worst and for any reason you split, there can be no argument for someone demanding backdated funds for paying more.
Aside from that, your salaries could change in the future and you may end up earning more in which case it would be equal – or nearabout – anyway.
Ultimately, it is your decision but it is nice to feel that you are on an equal footing with your partner, whether or not they earn a bit more.
If the roles were reversed and you were earning more, perhaps you would also want to split the bills 50-50.

title: Five ways to mend a broken housing market, according to experts
lead: The Government is considering boosts to help first-time buyers in next month’s Autumn Statement – but experts are skeptical over how effective they will be
author: Callum Mason

body.text: Back in 1970, the average property cost about £4,800. Factoring inflation, it means that had there not been any increase in the value, the same home would cost £60,000 today.
Except of course a typical home in the UK costs an awful lot more than that. Almost five times as much, the value of the typical home today is around £290,000.

Mortgage rates having rocketed over the last 18 months – and yesterday’s news from the Bank of England showed a contracting economy with rising unemployment. And yet even with this as the context, house prices have only marginally sunk over the past year in response: it’s no wonder that the discussion of our country’s broken housing market has intensified.

There is abundant evidence for how broken the situation is but perhaps the most telling statistic of all is that the rate of home ownership among young people has halved in the past four decades. This should worry us all, as it affects not just the younger people in the country.
So what to suggest instead? Below is what several housing experts say the Government needs to do in order to mend a broken housing system, and make homes truly affordable again.
“Without increasing housing supply, anything else is tinkering round the edges”, said Lucian Cook, research director at Savills estate agency.

The desire to build more homes is a common political ambition. The Conservative manifesto in 2019 targeted 300,000 a year by the middle of the decade, and Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer matched this at the party’s recent conference.

The Conservative Government has not achieved this target, managing to build just over 210,000 news homes in the year up to March, though the weakening housing market and inflation is not helping. Ian Mulheirn, former Treasury economist and now chief economist at the Tony Blair Institute, calculated  in 2018 that were we to build 300,000 homes for the next 20 years, compared with the lower numbers we’ve been achieving in recent years, then house prices will be 6 per cent lower in real terms.

It is unclear how policymakers will achieve their aims. One idea proposed by the Labour leader is reviewing the rules on building on green belt land, therefore allowing more of it.  Also to get “tough” with Nimbys – a term for those who oppose building and development in their local area – in allowing their views to have less sway in the planning process.

With prices falling and a weakening housing market, housebuilders are struggling, which will make it far more difficult to meet the target. Experts say the Government may have to become more closely involved in the processes, rather than relying on the private sector.
“If prices are falling, how will you get developers to build? Housebuilders are cutting back,” says Jonathan Rolande, founder of The National Association of Property Buyers.
“We have to say it’s up to the Government to provide councils with the resource to build homes, including council estates again. Why aren’t we building on brownfield and dormant land in our towns?”

The other big issue is funding of planning departments. Anna Clarke, director of policy and public affairs at The Housing Forum – a membership network for the housing sector – says only one in 10 local planning departments are fully staffed and this means a lack of staff to approve applications – particularly as new building safety and environmental protection regulations mean the demands on them are greater than ever before.

She also suggests a second problem. Last year the Government consulted on a number of changes to planning legislation under the Villiers amendment, named after Chipping Barnet MP Theresa Villiers. This would increase the number of reasons councils could not meet their house building targets. Ms Clarke says many local authorities are stalling on local plans while they wait for the Government to clarify policy.
“If the Government wants to meet its target of 300,000 homes a year, councils need the resources to deliver plans to deliver the right housing in the right places,” she says.
Tweaks to Stamp Duty (SDLT) have been a tool in the government’s arsenal when they have tried to stimulate the property market, and therefore economy.

Although these policies were hit with accusations that they inflated prices and kept the property market buoyant, rather than actually helping people get on to the housing ladder, experts have said that changes to the tax – albeit from a different approach – could actually boost housing affordability.

The tax is charged when you buy a property over a certain price – currently £250,000 – but reduced rates were introduced in 2020 to get transactions up again in the wake of the Covid pandemic. Before this, in 2017, the duty was abolished for first-time buyers for purchases of up to £300,000.
Stuart Adam, a senior economist at the Institute for Fiscal Studies, believes that changes to SDLT could help improve affordability.

“The Government could make it easier for people to move into housing that is more appropriate to their needs and preferences – upsize, downsize, relocate, or more – by reducing, or ideally abolishing it,” he says.

Although this would not reduce house prices immediately, Mr Adam says it would allocate housing better – older couples living in bigger family homes would be more likely to downsize, freeing up their large properties and increasing supply, which would lowers prices over time.
Others have also said that SDLT changes could provide a solution to housing affordability problems.

A limited-time reduction in SDLT for downsizers to facilitate older couples in big family houses moving in to smaller homes would be a good start, according to Jonathan Rolande, founder of The National Association of Property Buyers, with a cut to the tax making it cheaper for these people to move home.

“That would create demand for smaller flats by incentivising older families who no longer need their space to move,” he says. “It would also not be of huge cost to the exchequer as the people then moving into these larger homes would pay the tax.”

Mr Rolande personally believes this more targeted approach to SDLT changes should be time-limited to coax people into moving quickly, rather than providing it as a benefit that would always be there for them, should they choose to use it.

A policy proposed by former Bank of England economist Kate Barker over a decade ago, who was also commissioned by the Labour government under Gordon Brown to look at the problems in the housing market – with many of her recommendations remaining unimplemented – is to charge capital gains tax (CGT) on our main homes, and not just investment and second ones. Currently CGT is set at 28 per cent for higher rate tax payers, payable on the profits of the home, and 18 per cent for basic rate ones. But for people selling their main home there is no CGT to pay.

The Intergenerational Foundation, which campaigns for more economic fairness for younger people, has promoted Barker’s idea, which would likely mean a more significant fall in house prices, along with increasing the rates of CGT charged.
Sadly, the likelihood of this coming to fruition is low – Kate Barker herself said at the time that such a change “would undoubtedly face very strong public, and therefore, political, opposition”.
Prices in the rental market are soaring at the moment, and things are not expected to get any better soon.

The research team at estate agency Hamptons recently found that average rents are likely to outstrip wage inflation over the next few years, reaching £1,550 a month by the end of 2026 on current trajectories, an increase from £1,217 in December last year.
For those hoping to buy, this means far less ability to save money for a deposit – and for those who aren’t, it still means less disposable income.
For some experts, higher supply in this sector is another way to get costs down, though many solutions take long periods of time.

In terms of short-term answers, Emma Fildes, a buying agent at London-based firm Brick Weaver, says that the Government could encourage landlords and house builders to increase the number of homes built on existing sites.

“For example,  if you have a block that could go up another floor or two, further tax incentives for these sort of businesses to do so would also help increase and improve rental stock in the short term,” she says.
“For landlords who aren’t developers, so they are nervous of doing this, a tax incentive would help.”
Mr Rolande says that tax incentives to help landlords install property improvements that could cut bills for tenants would be another answer.

The Government recently scrapped plans to force landlords with energy-inefficient homes to upgrade, but Mr Rolande said a carrot, in the form of a tax incentive, rather than a stick, could be a solution.

“There’s often no incentive for a landlord to improve a home’s energy efficiency, but perhaps tax relief on things like insulation could help” he said. “That would bring down a tenant’s bills and save them money.”

Some believe the policy around addressing nutrient neutrality rules – regulations that require new housing developments not to increase the amount of nutrient pollution in protected rivers – is preventing house building in many areas because of water pollution rules.
Another issue is making sure homes are built in the right places for the right people.
“We think there is still mileage in looking at requiring new development to include a specified proportion of first-time buyer-only homes,” says Mr Cook.

He says that instead of applying “arbitrary headline-grabbing discounts” – as many new build developers do in order to ensure the listed price appears high – “the local market should determine their cost by limiting the class of buyer and their maximum size”.

And what about turning commercial property into residential homes, an idea touted after demand for office space reduced after the pandemic? Ms Clarke says there is a lot of interest in this, but that larger tower blocks are often unsuitable.
She says high street shop conversions could be more fitting, but that there is often opposition to this from councils who want to see the units remain open for their original use.

“We would like to see a more proactive approach from both local and central Government here to consider housing as a use of buildings where feasible, and where the previous use is no longer viable or sensible,” she says
Several policies are being considered by Chancellor Jeremy Hunt for November’s Autumn Statement, including the extension of a mortgage guarantee scheme and potentially the launch of a new Isa.

The mortgage guarantee scheme means borrowers are able to buy a home with just a 5 per cent deposit, because the government financially backs lenders if their customers were unable to pay their loans back.
Although the new scope of a Isa scheme is not clear, previous schemes seen first-time buyers have their deposits topped up with government bonuses.
But experts have questioned whether the policies are the right ones to improve the affordability of housing – particularly for people buying their first home.

Mr Cook says it’s difficult to see how a new Isa actually helps first-time buyers, given the cost of living crisis has impaired their attempts to save, while Ms Clarke says that even though the two policies can help individuals who are looking to buy, they are less helpful on a national scale.

“There is a risk that you just inflate buyers’ buying power, pushing up prices and so not making it any easier – overall – for young people to buy their first home, because supply is constrained” she says.
And Mr Rolande agrees. “Both these things would increase demand without increasing supply – which puts the ingredients in place for price rises,” he explains.

The property market has had years of so-called fudges – temporary sticking plasters to stimulate it – ranging from new Isas to Help to Buy, many of which are being covered in BBC’s new documentary series,  But to really solve the issues, experts clearly feel that more wholesale reform is needed.

title: UK mortgage lending to increase by lowest amount in a decade amid high rates and sluggish housing market
lead: Lenders are struggling to attract business – and brokers say they may have to drop rates to do so
author: Callum Mason

body.text: UK mortgage lending is set to record decade-low growth in 2023 and 2024, according to a forecast.

Mortgage loans are expected to rise just 1.5 per cent net in 2023 and two per cent net in 2024, which would represent the lowest growth over a two-year period in a decade, according to the EY ITEM Club Outlook for Financial Services.
High mortgage costs, leading to lower property sales, are dampening demand for borrowing.
In December 2021, the average interest on a five-year fixed mortgage was just 2.64 per cent, but now this figure sits at 5.87 per cent, according to the financial analytics firm MoneyFacts.

Some mortgage brokers have told  that lenders are likely to cut rates in the coming months as they try to attract more business but have warned customers to “manage expectations” about how cheap mortgages will get.

Justin Moy of EHF Mortgages, told : “Mortgage lenders are significantly behind their 2023 targets, hence some better rates over the last few months and that will continue into 2024, as the high street will want a strong positive start to the year.
But he added that the improvements were “small” and were not making a “significant” difference to affordability.

Nick Mendes, of John Charcol brokers, similarly warned customers to “manage expectations” and added: “Lenders will be balancing winning business but also ensuring that products remain profitable – 2023 has been a difficult year, with 2024 not looking any easier.”

Dan Cooper, UK head of banking and capital markets at EY, said: “The ‘higher for longer’ borrowing rates and ongoing cost-of-living pressures are continuing to have a very real impact on customers, and at the same time, banks are tightening their lending criteria.
“Banks are actively working to retain a strong capital position and support their customers in this challenging market.”

EY ITEM Club expects demand for borrowing to pick up within the next two years, as long as inflation continues to fall, the Bank of England cuts interest rates next year, and housing affordability improves.
Overall, it expects lending to grow by 2.8 per cent in 2025, though this still remains very low in historical terms.
And it warned that global events such as the crisis in the Middle East and the war in Ukraine could cause falls in consumer and business confidence and appetite to borrow.

title: As an aspiring first-time buyer, I’m begging Jeremy Hunt: don’t give us another Isa this Budget
lead: Lifetime Isas seem like a good product, but are they really solving the systemic problems with our housing market?
author: Callum Mason

body.text: In the mid-2010s, with the Conservative Party desperate to give some positive news to younger voters, chancellor George Osborne waved his magic wand and produced two new savings products for first-time property buyers: the Help to Buy Isa, and then the Lifetime Isa.

Both work slightly differently, but the gist is the same. Save money towards buying your first home, and the Government a) won’t tax you on the interest, and b) will give you a bonus of 25 per cent on top of whatever you save.

The first point was essentially moot. Interest rates were so low until two years ago that hardly anyone would have paid tax on their savings anyway. But the second seems like a win. What could be negative about being handed free money, on top of your own money?
Now there are rumours that the Treasury is considering introducing a new Isa for first-time buyers at this Autumn Statement.
And to this, as an aspiring first-time buyer, I say to Jeremy Hunt: for god’s sake, no!
There are two main reasons why a new Isa aren’t the answer to the housing crisis facing particularly younger people.
The first is that handing a 25 per cent government bonus to those who are lucky enough to be able to save money does not seem like a good use of public funds.

Imagine you have two people scaling a mountain face. One has a ladder and is slowly climbing, so you throw them a rope to help further. The other does not have a ladder. This person, you offer absolutely nothing. This in effect is how the bonus scheme works.
It gives a leg up to those on their way, and nothing to those who aren’t.

Secondly, the bonuses these schemes offer are essentially sticking plasters, which arguably make things worse – by pushing up property prices – without altering the overall problem of unaffordable housing.

Continuing with the trend of slightly tenuous metaphors, imagine you are in the middle of a training for a marathon and develop a pain in your knee. You can neck a couple of ibuprofens, continue training, and make your knee worse. Or, you can stop training, rest, and assess what the underlying cause of that knee pain is.
What we need to fix the housing crisis is to stop, and address the underlying problems, rather than handing out more magic pills.
That means building more homes – including a mix of social and private – and addressing systemic issues with our planning processes that make that so difficult.
Of course, there are things that do need to be fixed with the existing home ownership Isas.
For both products, there is a maximum property purchase price, which has not increased despite house prices soaring over the time they’ve been around.

This is particularly bad for those with Lifetime Isas, who are hit with a 25 per cent penalty if they withdraw without buying a home (and the penalty is larger than the government deposit, meaning people actively lose money) – leading to Martin Lewis declaring the product a “dead duck” today.

Mr Lewis has demanded the Chancellor Jeremy Hunt waive the penalty and, long-term, consider increases to the maximum purchase price. I don’t disagree with this. People opened the product in good-faith and it should be adapted to fit the times we live in to avoid punishing those who worked the system as they were told.
Fix the existing ones, sure, but let’s not kid ourselves that introducing new ones is a magic bullet – because in reality, they’re masking the real pain.
So this Budget, let’s end the Isa-era for good, and take some real steps to helping first-time buyers get on the property ladder.

title: How much you need to save each year for a comfortable retirement
lead: The key to building a retirement pot that matches your expectations is to start early, according to experts
author: Callum Mason

body.text: Retirees need a pension pot of at least £600,000 to have a ‘comfortable’ annual income in retirement, according to analysis from an investment company.
Figures from the Pensions and Lifetime Savings Association (PLSA) show a pensioner needs an annual pre-tax income of £43,482 for a ‘comfortable’ retirement, working out at £37,300 after tax.

Analysis from Fidelity International suggests that for men, a pot of £600,000 would be needed to achieve this income. For women, this figure would be even higher – at £640,000 – because of longer life expectancy.

A ‘comfortable’ retirement is the highest of the three strands of living standards on the PLSA’s scale and could mean a retiree having enough to enjoy three weeks in Europe every year, up to £1,500 for clothing and footwear each year and replacing their kitchen and bathroom every 10 to 15 years.
Fidelity’s calculations work on the basis that retirees will receive a full State Pension of £10,600 every year, and so they need to generate an extra £32,882 from their investments.
They work on the basis of a retirement at 67 and the assumption that men will live to 85 and women to 87.

Assuming real investment growth of 4 per cent per year, then according to calculations by AJ Bell’s head of retirement policy Tom Selby, a woman who starts saving at 30 would need to pay £7,200 per year – or £600 per month – to reach this figure, while a man would need to save £6,800 per year – or £566 per month.
Start saving earlier, and you’ll need less – £4,900 per year for a woman starting at 22. Start later, and you’ll need more – £12,400 per year for a woman starting at 40.
But the amounts needed may be even higher if circumstances go against you.

In fact, according to Fidelity, if a man was to encounter the worst outcomes in all cases – such as high inflation, low investment returns of two per cent and high investment charges of two per cent a year – the amount they need would climb to £2.8m, while for a woman it would climb to £3.1m.

In the best case scenario – low investment charges of 0.5 per cent a year, investment returns at 8 per cent and inflation at the lower rate of 2 per cent – a male would need just £405,000 and a female £420,000.

Ed Monk, associate director for personal investing at Fidelity International, said that factors beyond people’s control could affect retirement prospects, and added “planning for a certain cash income in retirement is difficult”.

He said: “Working longer, planning to reduce your income, paying lower fees and choosing to pass on an inheritance are all things you can influence. As, of course, is saving more during your working life to help build the biggest pot you can.”

Selby added: “The key to building a retirement pot that matches your expectations is to start as early as you can and save as much as you can afford, taking advantage of upfront pension tax relief, matched employer contributions and tax-free investment growth over the long-term.
“While an overall target in excess of half a million pounds might be intimidating, don’t let that put you off – saving is a whole lot easier if you break it down into manageable chunks.”
If you’ve not started saving for a pension yet, don’t panic – you can always start saving later in life.
And you’re not alone. One in four (24 per cent) of 40 to 75-year-olds do not have a private pension, Government data shows.
Have a look at our  guide: How to start properly saving for your pension in your 40s, 50s or 60s for tips on how to build money for retirement, later in your working life.

title: Interest rate decision: Inflation is more stubborn than any toddler, and the Bank is the exasperated parent
lead: The Bank of England has opted to hold interest rates – but don’t expect them to come down soon
author: Jessie Hewitson

body.text: We knew the type of inflation we were dealing with was stubborn, but today gives us an idea of how much so so. We’re talking a three-year-old who is refusing to eat their spinach levels of stubborn. And as any parent knows, once you’re in this position, you are in trouble.

Keeping with this analogy, the Bank  of England is the exasperated, somewhat powerless parent. Looking at the data published alongside its decision to keep the base rate at 5.25 per cent, it shows that even were it to decrease the base rate possibly even several times, it would not significantly change the dial on inflation next year.

The figures on the economy were quite a bit gloomier than expected, and we’re now now due to hit the 2 per cent target until the end of 2025, six months later than forecast only in August. Were the base rate to stay where it is, the country goes into recession next year and stays there for 12 months. If the Bank reduces the base rate, growth flat lines: the table outlining this scenario is a depressing sea of zeros. I for one am not going to be rushing out to book a holiday in the Caribbean any time soon given that a flatlining economy is the more positive of the two outcomes we’re looking at.

The monetary policy committee (the rate setting committee within the Bank, often known as the MPC) noted that a “restrictive policy stance” – code for higher rates – is “likely to be warranted for an extended period of time”. The MPC added that “a further rise in bank rate remained a possibility”.

So what does all of this mean for our wallets? Next year will be tough: rates will stay high, unemployment is likely to go up, the pay increases many have been able to obtain will become harder to come by. The Bank estimates that half of the impact of increasing rates is yet to feed through in the economy, which means many of us haven’t remortgaged yet so are living on old money that hasn’t been strangled by the rate rises.

My take home message from today is to make sure you are doing all the boring, sensible things.  When interest rates were low, any fool was able to make money from the stock market and feel like Warren Buffet.
Now you don’t need to risk your money to make a decent return; standard savings accounts are beating yields of many investment funds and this is likely to continue.

Thatwe are in an unprecedented situation is underlined by the fact that we are seeing house prices going down, rising unemployment, very gloomy news on GDP and falling inflation…. and the Bank is still not opting to cut rates.

Save as much as you can – one of the worst consequences of the 15 years of rock bottom rates is that we were deprived of any incentive to save, which is the best insurance policy I know of to allow you to sleep at night even when the economy weakens.
We are in a new world. Higher interest rates mean smaller mortgages and more expensive borrowing everywhere, and a reassessment of the risks we take with our money.
Sometimes boring is best – adults as well as kids will need to eat their spinach. Looking at the tables compiled by the economy wonks at the Bank of England, that is especially true now.

title: How the current property crash differs from 2008, and what it means for homeowners
lead: Whether you should buy in the current market is a heavily debated question
author: Jessie Hewitson

body.text: The housing price crash in 2008 happened shortly after I bought my first home. Almost the moment we completed, house prices started to fall and I had to watch as they plunged by 18 per cent on average in the year after the “for sale” sign came down in front of my block of flats. A financial genius I did not feel.
The crash was short and brutal for people working in the property business, but it gave hope to first-time buyers that they could finally buy at a reduced price.

Only they couldn’t, as lenders were in deep trouble after a housing bubble, created by cheap credit and lax lending, burst leaving banks in the US and Europe left holding over a trillion dollars of worthless investments.

This created an odd situation where lenders in the UK didn’t actually want to lend, which meant many buyers had to watch in dismay as cash-rich investors swooped in and gobbled up all the cheap property.

But this time, the banks are in good health. We are seeing house price falls – modest or more significant depending on where you live – and also reductions in mortgage rates too, as we cover in our story looking at how rates may fall to 4 per cent by next summer.
So you don’t have to be a moneyed investor to make the most of the price falls if you chose to buy.
Whether you should buy in the current market is a heavily debated question – perhaps the correction will develop into a crash so it would be wise to wait? Will you regret it like I did back in 2008?

The truth is no one knows, particularly as we cannot predict the course of the Israel-Hamas war. But at least if you want to, you can get a mortgage this time for a home that you will pay less for than last year – and that is a welcome difference from last time.
We want to hear from you about any thoughts, worries or trends related to money that you might have noticed.
Is there a story you want to tell or a company you think has wronged you? Do you want to perhaps highlight something you think isn’t receiving enough coverage?
Let us know: money@inews.co.uk

title: Rishi Sunak can’t afford to be generous to homeowners this Autumn Statement
lead: Economists are worried any boost to the housing market might stoke inflation – the Treasury’s response, however, is not exactly reassuring
author: Jessie Hewitson

body.text: Good news! I’m going to give everyone who reads this letter £10, but six months down the line I’m going to ask for £15 back. This is what two former Bank of England economists fear that the Government is doing with its plan to give the housing market a boost.

The form of this boost is likely to be announced in the Autumn Statement next month, in the form of the Lifetime Individual Savings Account, where the Government gives you free money to save more quickly for a deposit, and the Mortgage Guarantee Scheme, which allows you to get a home loan with a deposit as small as 5 per cent of the purchase price.
The economists we have spoken to are concerned that these measures could cause inflation – and therefore interest and mortgage rates – to go up.

But, as we report, in response to these fears, the Treasury has reassured  that the schemes it is considering were chosen specifically because not many people actually use them. So this is where we are: with a Treasury cherry-picking schemes to relaunch or extend precisely because they are not very successful. What a time to be alive.
To be fair to Rishi Sunak and his Chancellor, Jeremy Hunt, it is easy to understand why they need to be seen to be doing something without actually doing anything.

The Government doesn’t have money because the interest rate on our national debt has rocketed and the economy is stagnating, giving us less money to pay it all off. Yet senior politicians still need to give people a reason to vote Conservative.
It all neatly reflects the terrible economic bind we are in. Prepare for more measures in the Autumn Statement that appear to be very generous – but are really not very generous at all.

title: How to start properly saving for your pension in your 40s, 50s or 60s
lead: It’s never too late to start paying into a pension pot. Here’s how
author: Elizabeth Anderson

body.text: If you’ve left pension saving until later than ideal, you’re not alone. One in four (24 per cent) of 40 to 75-year-olds do not have a private pension, government data shows.

The problem is particularly acute for self-employed people, who have to set up their own pension. Government figures show there are about 4.2 million self-employed people in the UK. Around 45 per cent of these are not saving into a pension, according to figures from IPSE (the Association of Independent Professionals and the Self-Employed).
What should you do if you are in your 40s, 50s or 60s and haven’t saved much for your pension? Below we run through your options.
The first step is to open a private pension. If you are employed you will have one already, unless you opted out at some point. But if you are self-employed, you’ll need to open your own pension.
You may also want to open a separate private pension even if you are employed – in addition to your workplace one.

It’s easy to open a pension, and you do not need a financial adviser. There are many providers to choose from. These include traditional providers such as Aviva and Scottish Widows alongside newer providers such as Nutmeg, Vanguard and PensionBee.

A bit of research and online reading should help you decide which is worth a go. You may want to choose your own investments, but many offer ready-made portfolios that you can pay into without much thought.
Many give the choice of paying lump-sum payments or regular payments starting from £25 a month.

This depends on your age, your current income and how much income you want in retirement. The general advice from money advisers is to pay in half your age when you first start contributing. So if you start aged 40, you should aim for at least 20 per cent.

As an example of what a potential pot could give you, if you were to pay £350 a month into your pension from age 40, this could leave you with total pension savings worth £170,135 aged 67. This should give you an income of £583 a month (£7,000 a year) until age 99, according to an online pension calculator from provider PensionBee. If you started saving aged 50, to achieve the same amounts at age 67 you’d need to save around £600 a month. Aged 60, it’s £1,550 a month.

The £7,000 annual income should be on top of the state pension, currently worth £883 a month (£10,600 a year), providing you qualify for the full amount. So you could have pre-tax total annual income of £17,600.

Bear in mind there are tax incentives for saving into a pension as the government gives you tax relief on contributions. So a £350 contribution will only effectively cost you £280 if you are a basic-rate taxpayer, and £210 if you are a higher-rate taxpayer. If you make contributions through your business, you will save on corporation tax. If you are employed, your employer will also be contributing, reducing the cost to you further.
Colin Booth, 42, runs a digestive health supplement brand and recently opened a pension for the first time.

Colin, from Nottingham, founded Just For Tummies with his mother, Linda, in 2015. The business is going from strength to strength and Colin wanted to plan for the future by boosting his long-term investments, with the aim of retiring aged 60. His pension is managed by a financial adviser, and he pays in every month through his business.

“I’d never saved into a pension before my 40s. I’m ideally aiming for an income of £2,000 to £3,000 a month from the age of 60 so I have a lot to save to get there. I hope to take advantage of compound interest to boost the pot as much as possible,” he says.

You can pay up to £60,000 a year into a pension, including tax relief, or up to your annual earnings – whichever is lower. You can access your private pension from age 55 but this is rising to 57 in 2028.

Entrepreneur Penelope Silver, 48, from Greater Manchester, also recently opened a pension for the first time. Although she paid into a final salary pension while employed in her 20s, for years she didn’t give pensions another thought after she started her own business.
Penelope currently contributes 10 per cent of her revenue each month, with a view to potentially adding to the pot further at the end of her financial year, and increasing this as her business grows.

“I feel much more secure about my financial life in the later years. It’s never too late to start thinking about your financial future – even if you’re just getting the ball rolling in your late 40s or beyond,” she says.
The full UK state pension is only available to those with at least 35 years of qualifying national insurance contributions. You need at least 10 years of NI contributions to get any state pension.

If you are approaching state pension age and feel you will be short on NI contributions, perhaps because you took time out of work and did not claim benefits or you lived abroad for a while, you can make voluntary contributions for the past six years. The deadline is 5 April each year. You may be able to make top-ups dating back to 2006 if you are aged over 70.
Check out www.tax.service.gov.uk/check-your-state-pension to see your historical NI contributions.

A full year of NI contributions costs £824 a year, says Moneysavingexpert. Each year adds £302.64 a year to your state pension. So as long as you live three years after first receiving the state pension, it’ll be worth it. You may have years where you have partially contributed so you would pay less than the full £824.

Emma Gosling, 50, opened her first pension three years ago. Emma, a therapist from St Albans, had worked abroad for many years and had not paid into a private pension. Emma moved back to the UK in 2010, and worked for a publisher for 3.5 years before being made redundant and retraining as a self-employed therapist.
It was only after talking with a financial coach that she realised she should be saving into her own private pension, being self-employed and not able to benefit from an employer scheme.

Emma compared a few online pension providers before opening and paying into one. She aims to pay about 24 per cent of her monthly income into her pension. But as her income varies each month, it can be higher or lower. Emma now operates as a financial coach herself to help people avoid the same mistakes she made with pensions.
She says: “I wish I had paid more into my pension when I was employed and I wish someone had told me way back in 2013 that I should get a personal pension when I became self-employed.

“I am still deciding whether to make voluntary national insurance contributions because there are gaps in my NI record, which may reduce how much state pension I’ll get as you need 35 years of contributions to qualify for the full amount.”

title: Money Clinic: ‘I’m 61 but am already having to drawdown my pension. What should I do when it’s all gone?’
lead: There are many things to consider when it comes to rebuilding your pension
author: Charlotte Ransom

body.text: I currently have a self-invested personal pension (Sipp) which I’m in drawdown from (20 per cent tax free cash was taken). Due to certain things going on in my life at the moment, which I’d rather not go into, I have had to draw on it significantly. My pension fund will be close to zero in about 12 months, after which my circumstances will change & I will be able to pay into a pension once more. I am 61 years old. In a year’s time should I contribute to my existing Sipp, or can I open another one? I am looking to retire aged 72. My income is £62k per annum and savings currently stand at £45k.

: Our circumstances can change when we least expect it, and it’s good to hear that you will be in a position to continue to grow your pension again despite these unforeseen challenges. You are right to question whether you continue to contribute to your existing Sipp, or open another and an analysis of your present set-up will help in finding the right answer.

First of all, you should assess how much you are being charged in fees by your current Sipp provider; you may not have thought about it before, but it is crucial to know how much you are paying in total for your pension to be invested. The overall fees can cover a wide variety of costs – they typically include an investment management charge (often a percentage of the overall sum invested), custody or platform charges, transaction costs and underlying investment fees (to cover funds your provider may invest in).

You may also be paying for ongoing advice and, if so, you should question whether you will need this facility or if one-off advice would be sufficient when circumstances demand. These are the main drivers which cause the overall fee to mount up. For a pension, there will also likely be a low fixed annual charge and one-off costs, such as for income drawdown.

There is also the question of VAT – many providers quote their fees without VAT included, which will add another 20 per cent on top of the figure quoted. When you look at websites you will see quite a range in terms of how providers disclose their charges and many sites make it very difficult to understand what you are likely to pay. I would steer clear of any groups who are not fully transparent with their fees or who need to have a consultation prior to being able to divulge their fees – it simply isn’t necessary and is a clear warning signal as to how they intend to operate.

We believe investors should be able to pay no more than 1 per cent a year for their funds to be managed, with financial advice adding a further 0.35 per cent a year if taken. However, it’s not unusual for investors to pay 2 per cent or more once all the costs are totted up. While a 1 per cent difference per annum might not sound like much, over the 10-year period you anticipate contributing to a pension, you could have thousands more to spend in retirement with savings on fees.

You should also ensure your Sipp is properly diversified. If you have been saving into it for some time, it may not have the breadth and depth of investments it might have compared to more modern pension arrangements. For example, a home bias can result in a concentration of domestic investments rather than a broader, more global composition – potentially leading to increased risk and lower returns.

A wider range of investments gives you access to the growth potential of global stock markets, government and corporate bonds and potentially other asset classes such as commodities. This can be important; for example, not being able to benefit from thriving US markets over the last 10 years or so could have had a significant effect on the growth of your investments – a balanced investment mix is always advisable.

Once you have assessed whether your current Sipp is fit for purpose or not – and whether you are better off changing provider – then you can focus on growing your retirement pot. Although you are still working and earning £62,000 a year, you are only able to add £10,000 a year because you have accessed your pension and triggered what is known as the Money Purchase Annual Allowance (MPAA). However, you have 10 years to grow this pot and, if we assume returns of 5 per cent a year, that could produce an additional sum of just over £125,000 by the time you are ready to retire at 72.

You might want to fund these pension contributions from your £45,000 in savings and the rest from your salary, although bear in mind that your salary contributions will also be bolstered by the Government – every £10,000 you add in from your salary (including employer contributions) will in effect cost you £6,000.

As an additional boost, you will qualify for the state pension at age 67, so if you plan to work until 72 you could also invest these funds as you go along if you are living comfortably on your salary. The full state pension is just over £10,600 a year and could help add welcome funds at retirement, especially if you use the annual ISA wrapper and can maximise tax-free growth.

Alternatively, you can defer taking your state pension. For every nine weeks you do so, it rises by 1 per cent, or 5.8 per cent a year. If you defer your pension for five years, you will get an extra 29 per cent (of £10,600 currently) for life. The advantage of taking the alternative route, and investing your state pension as you go along, is that investment returns will be tax free if you shelter the funds in an Isa.

As you can see, there are several different options to consider. The good news is that you have a plan and will be circumnavigating the unexpected challenges. As a result, you are still well placed to build up a reasonable pension pot over the next few years.

title: Bank of England sounds alarm on hitting inflation target
lead: Labour market warnings and bank failures challenge experts as digital era accelerates
author: David Connett

body.text: The Bank of England’s chief ­economist, Huw Pill, has warned that the UK’s persistently high inflation will not necessarily fall quickly, even as demand slows.

The judgement of the interest-rate-setting Monetary Policy ­Committee (MPC) has switched from high ­inflation being associated with ­demand factors, to price rises being more influenced by supply factors, Mr Pill said during a Bank presentation.
“We can be less sanguine about the idea that the slowing of demand, the slowing of activity that we are ­seeing, will lead to inflation returning to ­target,” he said.
This week the MPC voted by six votes to three to hold the benchmark interest rate at 5.25 per cent for a second month in a row.
MPC member Jonathan Haskel said failures in the UK’s labour ­market, which meant it was not working as well as it should, could keep interest rates high.

Mr Haskel said the ability of the labour market to match workers with vacancies appeared to have deteriorated.“With an impaired labour market, interest rates would have to remain higher for longer than would otherwise be the case,” he added.
The Bank also warned that ­regulators need to make sure that banks operating in the UK ­retain adequate financial buffers as ­technological advances are increasng the risk of bank runs.
Determining appropriate levels of bank reserves was a challenge, ­Andrew Hauser, the Bank’s director of markets said.
Regulators worldwide have since been grappling with the risk of bank runs as the digital era accelerates.
Earlier this year, some regional US banks and Credit Suisse suffered massive deposit runs, causing some to fail and regulators to intervene to halt a wider crisis.
The sudden collapse of US lender Silicon Valley Bank in March surprised officials as customers rushed to empty their accounts using online banking services.

Mr Hauser said central banks also needed to judge whether balance sheets should rest after ­expanding hugely over years of bond-buying. He said it would be unwise for them to shrink balance sheets too far.

title: ‘Director fatigue’, rising costs and debt demands behind soaring number of firms going bust, say experts
lead: Bosses are calling it quits after pandemic and economic struggles, with company failures hitting highest level since peak of financial crisis
author: David Connett

body.text: Company directors getting worn out by battling the pandemic, rising costs and growing demands from creditors are behind a big rise in the number of companies going bust, insolvency experts have warned.
They highlighted “director fatigue”‘ as latest data showed the number of companies going out of business reaching the highest level since the peak of the financial crisis in 2009.

The number of company insolvencies between July and September was 10 per cent higher than the same period last year, while the number of creditors’ voluntary liquidations was at its highest since 1960, when the numbers were first collected.

According to the Insolvency Service, there were 6,208 company failures over the last year, with construction firms hard hit with the highest number of insolvencies at 4,276. Hospitality and retail companies also faced insolvency proceedings.

A total of 4,965 firms were closed down voluntarily by directors (CVLs). There were also 735 compulsory liquidations, 466 administrations, 41 company voluntary arrangements (CVAs), and one receivership appointment.
One in 191 active companies entered liquidation between 1 October 2022 and 30 September 2023, the Insolvency Service said.
Christina Fitzgerald, former president of R3, the UK’s insolvency and restructuring trade body, said the numbers were the result of a “perfect storm of economic issues”.
“A combination of director fatigue, rising costs and increased creditor pressure mean more firms are turning to a corporate insolvency process to resolve their financial issues.

“After years of battling through the pandemic, supply chain issues, increasing costs, rising inflation and requests for higher wages, many directors have simply had enough and are calling it a day while that choice is still theirs.

“Compulsory liquidation numbers have reached a four-year high – partly because of legislation preventing them and then making the winding-up petition threshold higher in the aftermath of the pandemic, but also because these firms are now under their own pressures, and are calling in debts in the hope of balancing their own books.

“Trading conditions are tough right now. People are worried about money and reluctant to spend on anything other than the basics – and even then, are looking for the best deal possible – while costs are rising and the economy remains turbulent.
Simon Edel, a restructuring expert at EY-Parthenon, said the latest figures showed the challenges of staying in business were starting to hit bigger companies.
“Since the pandemic, insolvency activity had been heavily focused among smaller companies, but we are now seeing increased activity in the mid-market as macroeconomic and financing stresses build.

“These mid-market companies – whose balance sheets had previously been cushioned by extended maturities and Covid-19 support measures – are now facing several liabilities, including the repayment of pandemic loans, higher refinancing hurdles and ongoing supply, cost and interest rate pressures.

“This stress is manifesting in rising profit warnings and mid-market administration appointments. EY-Parthenon’s latest Profit Warnings report for the July-September period found that a third (33 per cent) of profit warnings during the quarter came from mid-market listed companies – the highest proportion of warnings from this group in almost 13 years.
“The rise in corporate-led restructuring activity is also significant among “large cap” companies, where the focus is still largely on refinancing and liability planning.

“It is critical that companies adapt their financial and operating structures to fundamental changes in their market and the rising cost of capital by contingency planning and seeking board advice – delaying action risks affecting value.”

title: Premium Bonds winners November 2023: Winning NS&I numbers this month and how to check if you won
lead: Two premium bond holders – one from the West Midlands and one from West Sussex – win this month’s top prize of £1m
author: Alex Finnis

body.text: Two premium bonds holders – one from the West Midlands and one from West Sussex – are the lucky recipients of this month’s top prize of £1m.

The first bond number drawn was 060PS313350 and is held by a winner based in the West Midlands. The winner has a holding of £5,050 in premium bonds and purchased their winning bond in May 2000. They become the fifth jackpot winner from the West Midlands.

The second millionaire is based in West Sussex and holds Bond number 466PQ093728. The winner has £50,000 in Premium Bonds and purchased their winning Bond in August 2021. This win makes them the 12th millionaire from West Sussex.
In the November 2023 prize draw more than 5.7 million prizes will be handed out in total, worth more than £471m.
Premium bonds are one of the UK’s most popular ways to save, and can be a fun option just as long as you’re happy to accept that there’s no guarantee they will offer a consistent income.
The form of investment is offered by National Savings and Investment (NS&I), a savings bank owned by the Government.
Instead of earning regular interest on their money in the usual way, holders of the bonds are entered into a random draw at the start of every month, with tax-free prizes worth between £25 and £1m.
The prize fund rate has increased significantly this year – reflecting the UK’s rising interest rates – and currently stands at its highest point in almost a quarter of a century.
